This doesn't make sense, it literally says that 'this method enhances our understanding of translation; it works by pooling the results of another method with the results of **this method itself**' -- that's an infinitely recursive definition. The German version asserts the necessity for change, but not that the change will indeed take place. The English version, on the other hand, asserts that the changes will definitely take place. The German sentence is modal, while the English sentence is factual.   Compare this to 'Handlungsbedarf in der CO2-Reduktion wird es geben' and 'CO2 reduction will take place', which are indeed very different in what they entail.

these terms are not synonymous. Choose one and define it properly, with a reference to the literature.   Most of the German-English examples have a difference in the initial position, which is normally reserved for Topic, not Focus, in both languages. Obviously, there can be contrastive topics in initial position, which are normally phonetically stressed, but this does not confer them focus.   Of course, there are many different definitions of topic/focus, Thema/Rhema, Topic/Comment, aboutness, at-issueness etc. But precisely because of that, it would be good to give clear definitions and situate the terms used here in the wider context of linguistic approaches to focus.
